Context: Methods: BD was performed in high-fat diet (HFD)-fed FXR knockout (FXRko) and wild-type (WT) animals.

We previously demonstrated that delivery of BAs to the distal intestine using bile diversion (BD) surgery improved high-fat diet (HFD)-induced obesity, insulin resistance, and energy expenditure in wild-type (WT) mice (4).
Mucosal adaptation to enteral nutrients is dependent on the physiologic actions of glucagon-like peptide-2 in mice.
Farnesoid X receptor deficiency improves glucose homeostasis in mouse models of obesity.
Microbiome remodelling leads to inhibition of intestinal farnesoid X receptor signalling and decreased obesity.
Methods: BD was performed in high-fat diet (HFD)-fed FXR knockout (FXRko) and wild-type (WT) animals.
Methods Mice and surgery Age-matched FXR knockout (FXRko) mice and their WT littermate male mice purchased from Jackson Laboratory (Bar Harbor, Maine) were used in the current study.
Another limitation of this study is that using a global knockout of FXR cannot differentiate the tissue-specific effects of FXR activity or modulation.

Our results contribute to the understanding of the mixed metabolic phenotypes observed in global FXR knockouts and provide the potential to develop tissue-specific FXR manipulations for the treatment of obesity and type 2 diabetes.
